key_points: Vaccine uptake among teenagers has stalled with about half of parents of 12-17 year-olds reporting their teen has been vaccinated.
About 16% of parents of children ages 5 to 11 report their child has been vaccinated, with another 13% planning to do so 'right away'.
Three in ten parents of both teens and younger children say they will 'definitely not' get their child vaccinated for COVID-19.
Safety and potential side effects of COVID-19 vaccines for kids are major concerns among parents.
Hispanic, Black, and lower-income parents express more concern over access barriers to vaccinating their children.
Pediatricians are the most trusted source of vaccine information for parents, though fewer than half have discussed COVID-19 vaccinations with their child's healthcare provider.
About half of parents say their child's school provided information or encouraged COVID-19 vaccination.
Parents who report their school encouraged COVID-19 vaccination are more likely to have vaccinated children.
Parents of 5-17 year-olds largely oppose schools requiring COVID-19 vaccines for eligible students, preferring personal choice over collective responsibility.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant negative impact on parents and families, affecting mental health, financial stability, and children's education especially among lower-income and minority groups.
